tit.cmt: (Hie Taisha shrine)削除しました。用語統一しました。

sen.j: 祭神大山咋神（東本宮）大己貴神（西本宮）

sen.j: 社格式内社（名神大）・二十二社・官幣大社・別表神社
sen.e: Shrine Ranking of Hiyoshi Taisha shrine - Shikiuchi sha or Myojin Taisha, (Shinto shrines listed in the Engishiki, books of regulations and laws), Nijuni-sha Shrines (the 22 most important Shinto shrines, as designated during the Heian period), Kanpei-taisha (Major Imperial shrine), and Beppyo jinja (Shrines on the Special List of Association of Shinto Shrines).

sen.e: Annual festival is held between April 12th and 15th (Sanno Festival).

sen.j: 日吉大社（ひよしたいしゃ、かつては「ひえたいしゃ」）は、滋賀県大津市坂本 (大津市)にある神社。
sen.e: Hiyoshi Taisha shrine (Hie Taisha Shrine) is in Sakamoto of Otsu City in Shiga Prefecture.
Hiyoshi Taisha shrine (Hie Taisha Shrine) is in Sakamoto of Otsu City in Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 日本全国に約2000社ある日吉神社の総本宮である。
sen.e: Hiyoshi Taisha is the main shrine amongst 2,000 Hiyoshi branch shrines across Japan.
Hiyoshi Taisha is the main shrine amongst 2,000 Hiyoshi branch shrines across Japan.
Hiyoshi Taisha is the main shrine amongst 2,000 Hiyoshi branch shrines across Japan.

sen.j: 旧社格は官幣大社。
sen.e: The former shrine ranking is Kanpei-taisha (Major Imperial shrine).
The former shrine ranking is Kanpei-taisha (Major Imperial shrine).

sen.j: 中世には二十二社の下八社のひとつとされた。
sen.e: In the medieval period, it was categorized into one of the Lower Eight shrines of Nijuni-sha Shrines (the 22 most important Shinto shrines were classified into three types: Upper seven shrines, Middle seven shrines, Lower eight shrines)
sen.cmt: 「下八社」とされたのは11世紀のようです。原文には「中世」と記述されていますが、曖昧なため「In the 11th century」とした方がはっきりすると思います。

sen.j: 西本宮と東本宮を中心に、400,000m&ampsup2の境内を持つ。
sen.e: Hiyoshi Taisha shrine has precincts of 400,000㎡ mainly consisting East and West shrine.

sen.j: ニホンザルを神使として崇拝することで知られている。

sen.e: Ohoyamakuhi no kami god is enshrined at East shrine, and Onamuchi no kami god (Okuninushi god) is enshrined at West shrine.

sen.j: 2つの本宮と以下の5つの摂社は日吉七社・山王七社と呼ばれている。

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 文献では、『古事記』に「大山咋神、亦の名を山末之大主神。此の神は近淡海国の日枝の山に坐し」とあるのが初見である。
sen.e: Hiyoshi Taisha shrine first appeared in the book called "Kojiki" (the Record of Ancient Matters), which says "Ohoyamakuhi no kami god is also called Yamasueno Onushino Kami who is enshrined at Mt. Hiei in Chihatsu Ahaumi Province, which refers to Hiyoshi Taisha shrine.

Hiyoshi Taisha shrine first appeared in the book called "Kojiki" (the Record of Ancient Matters), which says "Ohoyamakuhi no kami god is also called Yamasueno Onushino Kami who is enshrined at Mt. Hiei in Chihatsu Ahaumi Province, which refers to Hiyoshi Taisha shrine.

Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine first appeared in the book called "Kojiki" (the Record of Ancient Matters), which says 'Ohoyamakuhi no kami god is also called Yamasueno Onushino Kami who is enshrined at Mt. Hiei in Chihatsu Ahaumi Province, which refers to Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine.'
sen.cmt: 用語統一しました。スペース削除しました。記号を修正しました。

sen.j: 牛尾山（八王子山）山頂に磐座があり、これが元々の信仰の地であった。
sen.e: Iwakura (dwelling place of a god, usually in reference to a large rock) is placed on the top of Mt. Ushio (Mt. Hachioji), and it was originally the place of the worship.
Iwakura (dwelling place of a god, usually in reference to a large rock) is placed on the top of Mt. Ushio (Mt. Hachioji), and it was originally a place of worship.
Iwakura (dwelling place of a god, usually in reference to a large rock) is placed on the top of Mt. Ushio (Mt. Hachioji), and it was originally a place of worship.

sen.j: 磐座を挟んで2社の奥宮（牛尾神社・三宮神社）があり、現在の東本宮は崇神天皇7年に牛尾神社の里宮として創祀されたものと伝えられている。
sen.e: There were two Okumiya shrines on the side of Iwakura (Shrine built on the top of a mountain as a worship space), Ushio shrine and Sannomiya shrine, and the present East shrine was first established as Satomiya shrine (shrine built in village area as a worship space) of Ushio Shrine in B.C 91.

There were two Okumiya shrines on the side of Iwakura (Shrine built on the top of a mountain as a worship space), Ushio shrine and Sannomiya shrine, and the present East shrine was first established as Satomiya shrine (shrine built in village area as a worship space) of Ushio Shrine in B.C 91.

There were two Okumiya shrines on the side of Iwakura (Shrine built on the top of a mountain as a worship space), Ushio shrine and Sannomiya shrine, and the present East shrine was first established as Satomiya shrine (shrine built in village area as a worship space) of Ushio Shrine in B.C. 91.
sen.cmt: スペース削除しました。

sen.j: 三宮神社に対する里宮は樹下神社である。
sen.e: Satomiya shrine of Sannomiya Shrine is Kinosita shrine.
Satomiya shrine of Sannomiya Shrine is Kinosita shrine.
Satomiya shrine of Sannomiya Shrine is Kinoshita shrine.

sen.j: 近江京遷都の翌年である天智天皇7年、大津京鎮護のため大神神社の神を勧請した。
sen.e: In 667, a year after Omikyo-sento (Transferring of the national capital to Omi Kyo), the god of Omiwa shrine was transferred to Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine for the sake of protection of Otsu kyo (Shiga Prefecture).

In 667, a year after Omikyo-sento (Transferring of the national capital to Omi Kyo), the god of Omiwa shrine was transferred to Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine for the sake of protecting Otsu kyo (Shiga Prefecture).

In 667, a year after Omikyo-sento (Transferring of the national capital to Omi Kyo), the god of Omiwa shrine was transferred to Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine for the sake of protecting Otsu kyo (Shiga Prefecture).

sen.j: 以降、元々の神である大山咋神よりも大己貴神の方が上位とみなされるようになり、「大宮」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Since then, the West shrine was called Omiya shrine as Onamuchi no kami god (the god enshrined at the West shrine) have been positioned as the one with higher rank than Ohoyamakuhi no kami god.
Since then, the West shrine was called Omiya shrine as Onamuchi no kami god (the god enshrined at the West shrine) have been positioned as having a higher rank than the Ohoyamakuhi no kami god.
Since then, the West shrine was called Omiya shrine as Onamuchi no kami god (the god enshrined at the West shrine) have been positioned as having a higher rank than the Ohoyamakuhi no kami god.

sen.j: 平安京遷都により、当社が京の鬼門に当たることから、鬼門除け・災難除けの社として崇敬されるようになった。
sen.e: Due to the capital transfer to Heisan Kyo (Kyoto), Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine started to receive reputation as the shrine of protecting from evils and disasters as it was located at Kimon (the northeastern (unlucky) direction) of the nation's new capital.

Due to the capital being transfered to Heisan Kyo (Kyoto), Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine started to have a reputation as a shrine that protected people from evil and disasters as it was located at Kimon (the northeastern (unlucky) direction) of the nation's new capital.

Due to the capital being transferred to Heian Kyo (Kyoto), Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine started to have a reputation as a shrine that protected people from evil and disasters as it was located at Kimon (the northeastern (unlucky) direction) of the nation's new capital.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳では名神大社に列格し、さらに二十二社の一社ともなった。
sen.e: In Engishiki Jinmyocho (the list of deities in Engishiki, books of regulations and laws), Hiyoshi Taisha shrine was listed as one of Nijuni-sha Shrines (the 22 most important Shinto shrines, as designated during the Heian period), as well as Myojin Taisha (Shinto shrines listed in the Engishiki).

In Engishiki Jinmyocho (the list of deities in Engishiki, books of regulations and laws), Hiyoshi Taisha shrine was listed as one of Nijuni-sha Shrines (the 22 most important Shinto shrines, as designated during the Heian period), as well as Myojin Taisha (Shinto shrines listed in the Engishiki).

In Engishiki Jinmyocho (the list of deities in Engishiki, books of regulations and laws), Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine was listed as one of Nijuni-sha Shrines (the 22 most important Shinto shrines, as designated during the Heian period), as well as Myojin Taisha (Shinto shrines listed in the Engishiki).

sen.j: 最澄が比叡山上に延暦寺を建立し、比叡山の地主神である当社を、天台宗・延暦寺の守護神として崇敬した。
sen.e: Saicho, a Buddhism monk, erected Enryakuji temple on the Mt Hiei, and the Hyoshi Taisha shrine, jinushigami (tutelary deity) of Mt. Hiei, was admired as the shrine for protection of Enryakuji temple of Tendai syu (buddhism sect).

Saicho, a Buddhism monk, erected Enryakuji temple on the Mt Hiei, and the Hyoshi Taisha shrine, jinushigami (tutelary deity) of Mt. Hiei, was admired as a shrine for protection of Enryakuji temple of Tendai syu (buddhism sect).

Saicho, a Buddhism monk, erected Enryaku-ji temple on the Mt Hiei, and the Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine, jinushigami (tutelary deity) of Mt. Hiei, was admired as a shrine for protection of Enryaku-ji temple of Tendai sect.
sen.cmt: 用語統一しました。スペル修正しました。

sen.j: 中国の天台宗の本山である天台山国清寺で祀られていた山王元弼真君にならって山王権現と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: Hiyoshi Taisha shrine was called as Sanno Gongen, named after San-no Genhitsu shinkun enshrined in Tendai-san Kokusei-ji Temple, the head temple of Tendai Shu in China.
Hiyoshi Taisha shrine was called Sanno Gongen, named after San-no Genhitsu shinkun enshrined in Tendai-san Kokusei-ji Temple, the head temple of Tendai Shu in China.
Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine was called Sanno Gongen, named after San-no Genhitsu shinkun enshrined in Tendai-san Kokusei-ji Temple, the head temple of Tendai sect in China.

sen.j: 延暦寺では、山王権現に対する信仰と天台宗の教えを結びつけて山王神道を説いた。
sen.e: Enryakuji temple taught Sanno-Shinto, a type of shintoism linked to doctrine of Tendai syu religion and worship towards Sanno-gongen.
Enryakuji temple taught Sanno-Shinto, a type of shintoism linked to the doctrine of Tendai syu religion and worshiped Sanno-gongen.
Enryaku-ji Temple taught Sanno-Shinto, a type of shintoism linked to the doctrine of Tendai sect religion and worshipped Sanno-gongen.

sen.j: 中世に比叡山の僧兵が強訴のために担ぎ出した神輿は日吉大社のものである。
sen.e: In the medieval period, it was Mikoshi from Hiyoshi Taisha shrine (portable shrine carried in festivals) which was used for petition by Monks of Mt.Hiei.
In the medieval period, it was Mikoshi from Hiyoshi Taisha shrine (portable shrine carried in festivals) which Monks of Mt.Hiei used to carry out petitions.
In the medieval period, it was Mikoshi from Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine (portable shrine carried in festivals) which Monks of Mt. Hiei used to carry out petitions.
sen.cmt: 用語統一しました。スペース挿入しました。

sen.j: 天台宗が全国に広がる過程で、日吉社も全国に勧請・創建された。
sen.e: Branches of Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine were established and gods were transferred to those branches in the course of preaching of Tendai syu across Japan.
Branches of Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine were established and gods were transferred to those branches while preaching Tendai syu across Japan.
Branches of Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine were established and gods were transferred to those branches while preaching Tendai sect across Japan.

sen.j: 元亀2年（1571年）、織田信長の比叡山焼き討ち (1571年)により日吉大社も灰燼に帰した。
sen.e: In 1571, Hiyoshi Taisha shrine was destroyed through the fire attack against Mt. Hiei by Nobunaga ODA.
In 1571, Hiyoshi Taisha shrine was destroyed in fire by an attack on Mt. Hiei by Nobunaga ODA.
In 1571, Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine was destroyed in fire by an attack on Mt. Hiei by Nobunaga ODA.

sen.j: 現在見られる建造物は安土桃山時代以降に再建されたものである。
sen.e: Present buildings were re-constructed after Azuchi-Momoyama period.
Present buildings were re-constructed after the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
Present buildings were re-constructed after the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
sen.cmt: スペース削除しました。

sen.j: 信長の死後、豊臣秀吉は当社の復興に尽力した。
sen.e: After the death of Nobunaga, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI contributed to the rehabilitation of the Shrine.
After the death of Nobunaga, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI contributed to the rehabilitation of the Shrine.
After the death of Nobunaga, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI contributed to the rehabilitation of the Shrine.

sen.j: これは、秀吉の幼名を「日吉丸」といい、あだ名が「猿」であることから、当社を特別な神社と考えたためである。
sen.e: Hideyoshi's childhood name "Hiyoshi Maru" and nickname "Saru"(monkey) gave him an idea that this shrine was important to him.
Hideyoshi's childhood name "Hiyoshi Maru" and nickname "Saru"(monkey) gave him the idea that this shrine was important to him.
Hideyoshi's childhood name 'Hiyoshi Maru' and nickname 'Saru' (monkey) gave him the idea that this shrine was important to him.
sen.cmt: 記号を修正しました。スペース挿入しました。

sen.j: 明治に入ると神仏分離令により、仏教色が廃された。
sen.e: Buddhism lost its momentum due to the execution of the Edict for Separation of Shinto and Buddhism in the Meiji Period.
Buddhism lost its momentum due to the execution of the Edict for the Separation of Shinto and Buddhism in the Meiji Period.
Buddhism lost its momentum due to the execution of the Edict for the Separation of Shinto and Buddhism in the Meiji period.

sen.j: また、本来の形に戻すとして、東本宮と西本宮の祭神を入れ替えて西本宮の大山咋神を主祭神とし、大物主神を祀る東本宮は摂社・大神神社に格下げした。
sen.e: In order to make the shrine as it was before, after enshrined gods of East shrine and West shrine were swapped, Ohoyamakuhi no kami god of West shrine becasme the main enshrined god, and East shrine enshrining Omononushi no kami god (Onamuchi no kami god) was demoted to Sessha (auxiliary shrine), Omiwa-jinja Shrine.

In order to make the shrine as it was before, after the enshrined gods of the East shrine and West shrine were swapped, Ohoyamakuhi no kami god of West shrine becasme the main enshrined god, and East shrine enshrining Omononushi no kami god (Onamuchi no kami god) was demoted to Sessha (auxiliary shrine), Omiwa-jinja Shrine.

In order to make the shrine as it was before, after the enshrined gods of the East shrine and West shrine were swapped, Ohoyamakuhi no kami god of West shrine became the main enshrined god, and East shrine enshrining Omononushi no kami god (Onamuchi no kami god) was demoted to Sessha (auxiliary shrine), Omiwa-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 昭和初年に元の形に復した。
sen.e: The buildings were completely recovered in 1926.

sen.j: かつては境内108社・境外108社と言われていた。
sen.e: Once, people said that Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine has 108 shrines within its precincts and 108 shrines outside its precincts (Keidai 108 sha and Keigai 108 sha, literally meaning precincts 108 shrines and outer precincts 108 shrines).

sen.j: 旧称は江戸時代までの神仏習合時代の名称である。
sen.e: The old name of the shrine is used up until the Edo period when both Shinto and Buddhism were still taught together.

sen.j: 東本宮境内の各社は、「大山咋神の家族および生活を導く神々」と説明されている。
sen.e: Also, shrines in the precincts of East Shrine are described as ones which protect families and lives of Ohoyamakuhi no kami god.

sen.j: 西本宮本殿 - 1586年（天正14年）の建立。
sen.e: The main shrine building of West Shrine - erected in 1586.

sen.j: 檜皮（ひわだ）葺きで、屋根形式は「日吉造」という、日吉大社特有のもの。
sen.e: The roof of Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine is featured in Hie design with hiwadabuki (cypress bark roof).
The roof of Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine is featured in Hie design with hiwadabuki (cypress bark roof).
The roof of Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine is featured in Hie design with hiwadabuki (cypress bark roof).

sen.j: 正面から見ると入母屋造に見える。
sen.e: From the front view, West shrine seems to have irimoya style (building with a half-hipped roof).

From the front view, West shrine seems to have irimoya style (building with a half-hipped roof).

sen.j: しかし、背面中央の庇（ひさし）部分の軒を切り上げ、この部分が垂直に断ち切られたような形態（縋破風）になっているのが特色。
sen.e: However, the roof is featured in Sugaruharu style, the eaves of the roof on the back of the building is raised, and the edge of the roof is shorter as if it is cut down vertically.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, the roof is featured in Sugaruharu style, the eaves of the roof on the back of the building is raised, and the edge of the roof is shorter as if being cut down vertically.
However, the roof is featured in Sugaruhafu style, the eaves of the roof on the back of the building is raised, and the edge of the roof is shorter as if being cut down vertically.

sen.j: 東本宮本殿 - 1595年（文禄4年）の建立。
sen.e: The main shrine building of East Shrine - erected in 1595.
The main shrine building of the East Shrine - erected in 1595.
The main shrine building of the East Shrine - erected in 1595.

sen.j: 建築形式は西本宮本殿に似る。
sen.e: Its arcitecture is similar that of West Shrine.
Its arcitecture is similar to that of the West Shrine.
Its architecture is similar to that of the West Shrine.

sen.j: 昭和初期までは「大神神社本殿」と呼ばれていた。
sen.e: Until the early period of Showa, East Shrine was called "the main shrine building of Omiwa Jinja shrine".
Until the early Showa period, the East Shrine was called "the main shrine building of Omiwa Jinja shrine".
Until the early Showa period, the East Shrine was called 'the main shrine building of Omiwa Jinja Shrine'.

sen.j: 以下の建造物は東照宮（江戸時代の建立）を除いて安土桃山時代の建立である。
sen.e: The buildings below are all built in the Azuchi-Momoyama period except for Toshu-gu shrine (established in the Edo Period).
The buildings below are all built in the Azuchi-Momoyama period except for Toshu-gu shrine (established in the Edo Period).
The buildings below are all built in the Azuchi-Momoyama period except for Tosho-gu Shrine (established in the Edo period).

sen.j: 摂社宇佐宮本殿 - 西本宮本殿、東本宮本殿と同様、屋根は日吉造である。
sen.e: sessha Usa-gu Honden (The main building of Usa-gu shrine, auxiliary shrine) - Its roof is featured with Hoyoshi design like the main buildings of Nihon-gu shrine and Higashi Hon-gu shrine.

sen.j: 摂社樹下神社（じゅげじんじゃ）本殿 - 樹下神社は東本宮と同じ敷地にあり、東本宮の参道と樹下神社の参道が直角に交わる、特異な配置になっている。
sen.e: The main building of Juge-Jinja Shrine (auxiliary shrine) - Juge-Jinja shrine is located at a unique place as it is in the same precincts of East Shrine,and Sando (an approach to shrine) of these shrines are intersected vertically.

The main building of Juge-Jinja Shrine (auxiliary shrine) - Juge-Jinja shrine is located in a unique location as it is in the same precinct as the East Shrine, and the Sando (an approach to the shrine) of these shrines intersect vertically.

sen.j: 昭和10年（1935年）6月29日、水害で流出し、指定解除された。
sen.e: The bridge was delisted as cultural heritage when it was debouched by the flood on 29th June in 1935.
